# Sankey Plot {#sankey}

### At the Beginning
```r
# library(BetterVis)
```

## BetterVis_Sankey_Single

For visualizing data flow, a Sankey diagram is the ideal choice.

### Data Input
```r
# Create sample data
# In your project: data("BetterVis_Sankey_Single_example", package="BetterVis")
set.seed(123)
df_sankey <- data.frame(
  AgeGroup = sample(c("18-30", "31-50", "51-70", ">70"), 500, replace = TRUE),
  Diagnosis = sample(c("GBM", "LUAD", "COAD"), 500, replace = TRUE),
  Treatment = sample(paste0("Treatment_", 1:4), 500, replace = TRUE),
  Outcome = sample(c("Cured", "Improved", "No_Improvement", "Deceased"), 500, replace = TRUE)
)

sankey_colors<-c("#F3BDA5", "#5FC8D1", "#e377c2", "#D8B4E2", "#1f77b4", "#F9D68D", "#FDFD96", "#B7E4C7", "#7FBEEB", "#E0E0E0", "#D8B4E2", "#AED9E0","#68d0ce","#e09a2a","#de6a73")
```

### Simple Example
```r
# Note: eval=FALSE as the function is not provided in user files
BetterVis_Sankey_Single(data = df_sankey, sankey_color = sankey_colors)
```
![](images/sankey_simple.png)

### Advanced Example
```r
# Note: eval=FALSE as the function is not provided in user files
BetterVis_Sankey_Single(data = df_sankey, sankey_alpha = 0.6, sankey_width = 0.4, border_color = "grey30",
                        sankey_text_size = 4, sankey_text_hjust = 0.5, sankey_text_vjust = 0.5,
                        bottom_text_size = 18, bottom_text_color = "grey30",
                        title = "Sankey Plot", title_size = 18,
                        text_adjust_global = 1,
                        sankey_color = sankey_colors)
```
